quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 5 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 5.9: Phenols Structure and Properties
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Phenol acidity, resonance stabilization, and physical properties

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the structure of phenol?
options: A hydroxyl group bonded directly to a benzene ring
A hydroxyl group bonded to a cyclohexane ring
A benzene ring with an ether linkage
An aldehyde group on a benzene ring
questions.explanation: Phenol (also known as carbolic acid) consists of a phenyl group ($-C_{6}H_{5}$) attached to a hydroxyl group ($-OH$).

questions.question: How does the acidity of phenol compare to that of ethanol?
options: Phenol is much more acidic than ethanol
Ethanol is much more acidic than phenol
Neither phenol nor ethanol can act as an acid
questions.explanation: Phenol ($pK_{a} \approx 10$) is roughly a million times more acidic than ethanol ($pK_{a} \approx 16$) because the resulting phenoxide ion is stabilized by resonance.

questions.question: Why is the phenoxide ion ($C_{6}H_{5}O^{-}$) more stable than an ethoxide ion ($CH_{3}CH_{2}O^{-}$)?
options: The negative charge is delocalized into the aromatic pi system
The ethoxide ion has resonance stabilization
The oxygen in phenol is more electronegative than in ethanol
questions.explanation: In the phenoxide ion, the negative charge on the oxygen is shared with the ortho and para positions of the benzene ring through resonance, lowering the energy of the ion.

questions.question: Phenol reacts with aqueous sodium hydroxide ($NaOH$) to form:
questions.explanation: Unlike alcohols, phenols are acidic enough to react with strong bases like $NaOH$ to form water-soluble salts.

questions.question: Which of the following reagents can be used to distinguish phenol from ethanol in the lab?
questions.explanation: Phenols react with neutral $FeCl_{3}$ to produce a characteristic violet or purple complex, whereas simple alcohols do not.

questions.question: How do electron-withdrawing groups (like $-NO_{2}$) on the benzene ring affect the acidity of phenol?
options: They have no effect on acidity
They turn phenol into a base
questions.explanation: Electron-withdrawing groups help stabilize the negative charge of the phenoxide ion further by pulling electron density away from the ring, making it easier for the phenol to lose a proton.

questions.question: Which molecule is the most acidic?
questions.explanation: With three strongly electron-withdrawing nitro groups, picric acid is a very strong organic acid ($pK_{a} \approx 0.38$).

questions.question: What is the physical state of pure phenol at room temperature?
questions.explanation: Pure phenol is a white crystalline solid at room temperature, though it often turns pink/red over time due to oxidation.

questions.question: Does phenol react with sodium bicarbonate ($NaHCO_{3}$)?
options: No, it is not a strong enough acid to release $CO_{2}$
Yes, it produces sodium phenoxide and $CO_{2}$ gas
Yes, but only in the presence of a catalyst
Only if the phenol is liquid
questions.explanation: While phenol is more acidic than alcohols, it is weaker than carbonic acid ($H_{2}CO_{3}$). Therefore, it cannot displace $CO_{2}$ from bicarbonate.

questions.question: Why does phenol have a higher boiling point than benzene?
options: Phenol has a higher molar mass
Benzene is a liquid and phenol is a solid
questions.explanation: The $-OH$ group in phenol allows for strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding, significantly increasing the energy required to vaporize the substance.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You clearly understand the electronic effects that make phenols unique.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You've grasped the concept of resonance stabilization in phenoxide ions.
scoreMessages.50: Good start. Focus on the difference in $pK_{a}$ between alcohols and phenols.
scoreMessages.0: Review the resonance structures of phenol and how they affect its acidity.
